@joecarter @JonathanMerritt I get arguments on both sides, but doesn't verses cited in article Jonathan (Matt 9) presuppose those "sinners"
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt ...we're somehow seeking Jesus? Pharisees were there with him too, but not "seeking him". He reclined w seekers
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt Similarly, Jesus are not w all Pharisees, but Simon who was "seeking" him in some sense, not outright rejecting
@chrishorst Life is always better, Chris, when you just go ahead and agree with me…unthinkingly and uncritically ;) #thingscultssay
@andrewtwalk Concur. Necessary evil.
@chrishorst Yeah, I did. I’m saying that having one’s views misrepresented may require a response…especially if done in public.
@andrewtwalk See my most-recent tweet to Joe :)
@chrishorst True, but ruffling feathers is a different response than having your views willfully misrepresented.
@joecarter In our click-bait e-culture, you're responding exactly as @JonathanMerritt hoped ("no fury like" & "may ruffle feathers").
RT @joecarter: @zhoag @JonathanMerritt Because the scholars he quotes aren't responding to what I wrote. JM never showed it to them, as he …
@Dblok110 @JonathanMerritt @zhoag Because I talked to some of the scholars quoted and they don't actually disagree with me.
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt @zhoag I think your original post was off base with what the scholarship says. Why can't you receive that?
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt @zhoag Are JC's tweeted "notions" at odds with Gospel Coalition article?  Seem to be making the same argument?
@JonathanMerritt @zhoag Selectively quoted, of course. Leaving out the most important tweet that provides the context for the discussion.
@JonathanMerritt @joecarter @zhoag (1) Long-time Christian here. Read this whole exch & am so sad. How do we honor God by sniping at each
@JonathanMerritt @joecarter @zhoag (2) other, accusing & defending?  Also: If I wait for ppl, esp fellow believers, to stop sinning, I'll
@JonathanMerritt @joecarter @zhoag (3) never assoc w/anyone (myself included). If I hang w/ppl w/the primary motive of calling them to repen
@JonathanMerritt @joecarter @zhoag (3) I'm dishonest (I'm a fellow beggar, not Jesus!) I may be wrong, but I read/hear God calling me to
@JonathanMerritt @joecarter @zhoag (4) witness to the transgen at my health food store by really caring abt her, giving her accptance she
@JonathanMerritt @joecarter @zhoag (5) prob doesn't get much, while being openly Christian & leaving the rest to God.
@joecarter @zhoag The notions quotes in the article via twitter and inserted at the bottom of the column.
@JonathanMerritt @zhoag "I asked him about the notions espoused by Carter" Did you mention my name or writings?
@zhoag saw that he invoked Hitler/Nazis already. We got to Godwin's law fast on this one.
.@joecarter just applying the same "logic" you are so fond of. Thanks for making my point. :)
@joecarter @zhoag Any time we start with "well, Jesus would have done this had he encountered..." usually leads to us creating our own Jesus
@WoooWoooMagic Preach that!
@aprilfiet @WoooWoooMagic @zhoag @joecarter indeed (and now to bed. Almost midnight here in the uk!)
@WoooWoooMagic @zhoag @ianjmatt @joecarter Wow. We wonder why people hate the church? The temple cleansing has nothing to do with sexuality.
@zhoag @ianjmatt @joecarter exactly.  God doesn't outcast or keep anyone away.  He loves the children, ALL of them, that he created.  There
@zhoag @ianjmatt @joecarter are no empty seats.  No one kicked out or turned out away.
@ianjmatt yep, it's not just a false analogy - it literally implies the opposite lesson. @WoooWoooMagic @joecarter
@WoooWoooMagic @joecarter @zhoag cleansing of the temple - Jesus' anger at those who stopped outsiders meeting God? Let's talk analogies?
@joecarter @zhoag pretty sure the Jesus I know would not react to anyone let alone "the gays" that way Joe.  Jesus loves, not hates.
@zhoag Yes, he would if they held the wedding in the Temple. (Not quite clear on how analogies work, are ya?)
@zhoag Perhaps @joecarter is confusing WWJD with WDJD. I doubt a revised bracelet is gonna help much.
.@joecarter says Jesus would make a whip of cords to drive out gay people at their abominable wedding! #joecarterlogic #logicalimplications
@JonathanMerritt @zhoag Did you get "nice notes" from Bock, Burge, or Green?
@JonathanMerritt Your article implies that your sources were responding to what I said. They weren't. That's a journalistic no-no. 1/2
@JonathanMerritt Would you like to correct it or should I take it up with @RNS? 2/2
RT @JonathanMerritt: @joecarter @zhoag I never implied that. I read your tweets. Got nice notes from most interviewees already on accuracy.
@joecarter I suppose since you confirmed that they never saw the articles that's probably how the feel. @JonathanMerritt #mediaintegrity
@sarahflashing @JonathanMerritt Nope.
@joecarter So your "notions" were via @JonathanMerritt & not in your own voice. WOW do these scholars in the article know they were duped?
@sarahflashing @JonathanMerritt @zhoag What's even worse, he didn't even ask them about what I wrote in the tweet (I asked them).
@JonathanMerritt "I asked him about the notions espoused by Carter" implies way more info than a tweet.  @joecarter @zhoag
@joecarter @zhoag I never implied that. I read your tweets. Got nice notes from most interviewees already on accuracy.
@zhoag @JonathanMerritt Because the scholars he quotes aren't responding to what I wrote. JM never showed it to them, as he implies he did.
RT @zhoag: @joecarter @JonathanMerritt Joe, you say the SAME THING Kevin said in your piece. How is this misrepresentation?
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt Joe, you say the SAME THING Kevin said in your piece. How is this misrepresentation?
@stevekmccoy @joecarter @JonathanMerritt I read his piece just now, & tweeted. Have already addressed similar illogic on the blog though.
@zhoag @joecarter @JonathanMerritt Zach, did you ever show the illogic or merely claim it?
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt haha zing! Such a "logical" defense! Good day, Joe.
@zhoag @JonathanMerritt Translation: "analogies and assumptions are false when they are analogies and assumptions that Zach disagrees with.
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt no. it’s illogical to the core. your indulgence in ‘logical implications’ are false analogies & assumptions.
@zhoag @JonathanMerritt What you mean is that you do not like where the logical conclusion leads to.
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt oh, and Joe, the tie-in at the end of your piece to cake bill discrimination is a stunning example of illogic.
RT @joecarter: .@JonathanMerritt Yes, it does when you misrepresent people's opinions. Why not mention the article I wrote? http://t.co/Q45…
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt Okay, thanks for clarifying.
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt Would you then disagree with what Kevin says at the end of this post? http://t.co/RTiuwMyxLi
@caldwa @JonathanMerritt No, I wouldn't. And I never said anything like that. I said he would not "party" w/ those who "flaunted their sin."
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt Would you say that Jesus only loved/interacted with those that he *knew* would respond in repentance?
@joecarter this one: "I claimed that Jesus didn't "party with" people flaunting their sin."// He was known as a drunk & friend of sinners.
@joecarter @Ramblin_Rino I gotta go. here's the deal. If Gods kindness leads to repentance, then as a dinner I must be close enough (1/2)
@joecarter @Ramblin_Rino to God in my sin to experience his kindness so that I repent. Kindness is not felt far off and out of relationship.
@Ramblin_Rino @NatePyle79 I think that is exactly what is meant by being "in, but not of" That is what the "of the world" is referring to.
@joecarter @NatePyle79 Think I'd draw it closer to the example of Anita Smith than Phil Robertson http://t.co/9b4BpW5T0t
@Ramblin_Rino @NatePyle79 That doesn't mean we should serve lemonade at a lynching, does it? Where do we draw the line?
@joecarter @NatePyle79 Being "of" the world means we let the world press us into its mold; can only go second mile/turn cheek if "in" world
@Ramblin_Rino @NatePyle79 How is being tolerant of celebrations of sin *not* being "of the world"?
@joecarter @NatePyle79 Not much of a chance to be "in" the world then, even if we don't plan to be "of" it; can't all live in Orange City!
@NatePyle79 @Ramblin_Rino No, no, no. All I'm saying: We shouldn't be at events whose purpose is to openly celebrate or engage in sin.
@joecarter @Ramblin_Rino you are saying that if we knew the sins of people we wouldn't be around them. Are you not?
@NatePyle79 @Ramblin_Rino I don't think so. I also suspect that woman was repentant.
@joecarter @Ramblin_Rino isn't that like that Pharisees saying "if he knew what kind of woman she was he wouldn't let her wash his feet."
@Ramblin_Rino @NatePyle79 No, not saying that. I'm saying we shouldn't be around (or quietly condone) celebrations of sinful actions.
@joecarter @NatePyle79 So, without explicit condemnation--exposure of personal sin--we are guilty of condoning it?
@NatePyle79 No, I don't think so--at least not obviously drunk. Unlike our culture, 1st century Jews didn't condone drunkenness. (Eph. 5:18)
@joecarter you don't think at least one person was drunk at the wedding he made wine for?
@NatePyle79 Nope, not saying that either. Jesus spent time with both, but was never around flaunting of sin without exposing/condemning it.
@joecarter so you are saying Jesus only spent time with unrepentant people?
@NatePyle79 @jaybakker No, that's not what I said or implied. That is the misperception JM is giving people about what I said, though.
@joecarter @jaybakker you are implying he was with them while yet unrepentant and while they may not repent. Which is the whole point.
@joecarter Seems to be exactly what the Pharisees accused him of... So you think they should've been mad giving their understanding of law?
@Ramblin_Rino @NatePyle79 @jaybakker Those too. That is why I don't think Jesus would uncritically attend an event that celebrated racism.
@joecarter @NatePyle79 @jaybakker Are we only talking about personal sins, here?  What about societal/structural evil?
@NatePyle79 @jaybakker What was scandalous was that Jesus said he had the power to forgive sins.
@joecarter @jaybakker what was scandalous about Jesus then? Calling out sin & never being around flaunted sin shouldn't have upset religious
@jaybakker No, according to the Bible, he seems to have called people out on for their private sins too.
@joecarter But privet sin was ok?
@jaybakker No, not what I said. My contention is merely that Jesus didn't "party" with people who were openly engaging in sinful activities.
@jaybakker of course they would. That's why we're called to constant repentance, the opposite of marinating in our sin.
@sarahflashing Repent and go sin no more are two different things... Do you think some one could never sin again?
@jaybakker how is it a loaded request? "Repent" and "Go and sin no more" are hardly periphery to Jesus' earthly ministry.
@sarahflashing No, I don't think so... Sure some times but not always, that's a loaded request if you really think about it.
@jaybakker don't you believe when Jesus ate with sinners he also said "go & sin no more" ?  @joecarter
@joecarter So you think Jesus really didn't eat with sinners? You think he made sure everybody repented before he had a meal with them?
@caldwa @jaybakker It's not a matter of "dirty" but about whether Jesus was tolerant of the open, flaunting of behavior he condemned.
@caldwa My wholly uncontroversial claim is that Jesus didn't quietly condone events where sin was openly flaunted and celebrated as normal.
@joecarter I suppose I just don't feel like "tolerate" is a way to describe Jesus love and way of being towards others.
@joecarter And to some extent, would you not say that are there not aspects of our lives where we "openly rebel and sin"? How is that diff?
@caldwa Yeah, lots of people are under the impression Jesus was tolerant of open, rebellious sinful events. That's what the debate is about.
@joecarter Is anyone suggesting that he would shrug? Jesus loves people where they are at. That experience potentiates a new way of living.
@jaybakker Yes, as long as Jesus is trying to save people from eternal damnation, he can hang out wherever he wants. 1/2
@joecarter I don't believe what we know of Jesus supports your views... Some times love is just being there and I think Jesus got that. 1/2
@joecarter 2/2 But there is so much theology we disagree on that it would be tuff for us to agree on much.
@jaybakker That'd be consistent with his character and his holiness. 2/2
@joecarter So as long as Jesus is critical he can hang out wherever he wants to?
@caldwa @jaybakker I believe Jesus would call porn actors/directors to repentance. He wouldn't just shrug and watch it happen.
@joecarter @jaybakker Extreme example, of course. But does that mean that there are places that are too "dirty" for Jesus to be present in?
@caldwa @jaybakker Would Jesus hang out (uncritically) on a set where a porn film was being shot? My contention is merely that he wouldn't.
@joecarter @jaybakker Isn't there a difference between "God hates sin" and "God can't be around sin"? Sounds like you're equating them.
@joecarter @jaybakker And, why would He encourage the sin that would put Him on the cross? That which He asked the Father to spare Him?
@jaybakker Because it would go against everything we know about Jesus. Jesus was God, God hates sin. Why would he encourage what he hated?
@joecarter Jesus made himself of no reputation, why would he worry about what other people thought if he condoning or not...
@joecarter To share a meal was to build a covenant with someone what makes  partying any different?
@jaybakker Because it implies that Jesus would condone the behavior he himself says is a sin, behavior that separates us from God.
@joecarter Why would flaunting matter, Matthew was a tax collector people were afraid to look him in the eye...
@jaybakker This one? "Jesus never interacted with anyone without at least *desiring* that they'd repent and follow him."
@joecarter You might want to reread your tweet.
@jaybakker @JonathanMerritt It's not plausible that Jesus desired that people he interacted with would repent of their sin?
@joecarter You just proved @JonathanMerritt point and what you're suggesting about Jesus makes no sense nor would it be plausible.
@caldwa @JonathanMerritt I think that Jesus never interacted with anyone without at least *desiring* that they'd repent and follow him.
@joecarter @JonathanMerritt Do you think that Jesus' love comes with a caveat that those he interacts with must have a resulting repentance?
